awd_titl_txt: The Influence of Mental Representations of Social Agents on Social Decision Preferences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Carolyn Parkinson at the University of California, Los Angeles, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating how mental representation of social agents affect decision processes involving these others. Defined as decisions that have direct or indirect social consequences, social decision-making has received much scientific attention over the past two decades. However, existing social decision-making research is impoverished insofar that very little is known about how the features of social targets implicated in social decision-making influence decision processes. Humans represent a wealth of information about others that profoundly shapes thought and behavior, yet it is unknown how these representations—dynamic mental models of others—impact decision preferences. Indeed, classic work from social cognitive psychology and neuroscience indicates that representations guide behavior in context, suggesting that mental representations likely play an important role in shaping social decision preferences. The current study aims to use computational methods to analyze functional magnetic resonance images and text data to (i) probe mental representations of common social decision-making targets (parents, friends) and (ii) relate structural features of these representations to social decision behavior. This project stands to make important theoretical contributions towards social decision-making research and contribute to ongoing efforts to build unifying and generalizable models of social decision-making. Notably, because social decision-making behavior has widespread impacts—ranging from individual well-being to aggregate societal phenomena—this project could inform future efforts to promote individually and societally adaptive social decision behavior.

This project will employ eminent computational methodologies to test how mental representations of real-life social partners shape social decision preferences as a function of the motivational goals and needs fulfilled by said agents. By combining multivariate pattern analysis of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data with natural language processing (NLP) and computational models of behavior, this project will comprehensively measure mental representations of everyday social partners and identify their relationship to social decision-making preferences. Concretely, this will involving (i) probing the neural representations of different kinds of social agents using fMRI, (ii) determining how neural representational overlap shapes social decision preferences, and (iii) use NLP tools on written content of social agents to help identify the representational content that drives differences in social decision preferences across social partners. This research will hopefully help lay the groundwork for the gradual establishment and refinement of unifying quantitative models of social decision-making, aiding both basic and applied scientific endeavors in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview.

In the project study, we set out to probe whether information about social decision preferences involving specific individuals is embedded in mental representations of said individuals. We were especially interested in testing social decision preferences within the category of close others, as little work on social decision preferences actively examines this distinction despite the fact that the most consequential choices we make on a daily basis affect multiple close others. We first tested to see how distinct representations of close others are constructed in the human brin. Next, we examined whether information about social choice preferences can be inferred from neural representations.

 

Results.

Probing How the Brain Constructs Unique Representations of Specific Others. If mental representations do indeed drive social decision preferences between close others, then the mind must first construct unique representations of these others. To test this intuition, we conducted a functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study. Participants (N = 63) nominated two close others (one parent, one friend) and completed a ratings task about themselves and these others while undergoing fMRI. Across four runs, participants made ratings about how well a set of 75 behaviors, preferences, and attitudes described themselves, their parent, and their friend. On each trial, participants used a button to indicate how well a given item (e.g., “feels comfortable talking about personal issues”) described either themselves, their parent, or their friend (1 = “Strongly disagree”, 4 = “Strongly agree”). We took behavioral and neural response patterns from trials each agent (self, parent, friend) and computed pairwise correlations between trials within modality (behavioral, fMRI). We then compared the similarity of (self, parent) and (self, friend) representations within both modalities to determine whether representations of close others differentially draw upon self-relevant information in their construction.

Behaviorally, we found that individuals construct representations of a close friend in more self-relevant terms than those of their parents (posterior Cohen’s d = 0.50, [0.28, 0.71] 89% highest density credible intervals). We examined whether several theoretically relevant brain regions (identified a priori) construct representations of a close friend or a parent more in terms of self-relevance (i.e., distance between self-representation and representation of another). We found modest evidence to suggest that (self, parent) representations are more similar than (self, friend) representations in bilateral TPJ and NAcc, whereas (self, friend) representations were modestly more similar than (self, parent) representation in mPFC. We ran an additional data-driven analysis (searchlight) post-hoc to determine if we missed any other brain regions that were sensitive to representational differences between parents and friends. We observed differences in representational similarity between parents and friends in additional cortical midline structures (vmPFC, dACC, precuneous), regions that are also sensitive to social processing.

Information About Social Decision Preferences is Embedded in Neural Representations of Close Others. In addition to the aforementioned judgment task, Study 1 participants also completed two runs of a social decision-making task that pit parent vs friend outcomes. One run involved hypothetical monetary payouts for parent and friend (monetary outcomes), and the other involved additional time the participant could spend with either person (social outcomes). Through the use of hierarchical modeling, we are able to estimate trial-level choice preferences between parents and friends, allow the preferences to vary randomly across participants, and then model the ensuing variability using participant-level information about mental representations.

In terms of neural representations predicting choice preferences with monetary outcomes, we found that greater (self, parent) neural similarity in the dmPFC was robustly associated with a greater tendency to favor parents over friends. Greater (self, friend) similarity in the right NAcc associated with a greater likelihood of favoring friends. Curiously, greater (self, friend) dissimilarity in the left NAcc was modestly associated with a greater likelihood of favoring friends. In terms of neural representations predicting choice preferences with social outcomes, we observed moderate evidence that greater (self, friend) dissimilarity in mPFC was associated with a greater propensity to favor friends over parents on the task. Greater (self, parent) similarity in the right NAcc was also associated with an increased propensity to favor parents over friends.
